questions.text: A diabetic patient comes with pre retinal Hemorrhages and neovascularization at disc. Treatment will be ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PRP Given is a scenario of diabetic retinopathy with proliferation. In such an advanced case, best possible management is to photocoagulation most of the retina except for the essential macular part to avoid further complications. By destroying the largely unused, ischemic extramacular retina , PRP reduces the area of ischemic tissue , which in turn reduces total vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) production in the eye and thereby reducing the impetus for neovascularization. PRP is indicated to treat retinal ischemia and retinal neovascularization , from whatever cause. However, PRP is most common for proliferative diabetic retinopathy. Option B and C: Focal laser Tx is used to treat macular edema due to focal leakage. While Grid Tx is used to treat macular edema due to diffuse leakage.

Highyeild:

Signs of Diabetic Retinopathy:- Retina thickening and edema (swelling) New blood vessels Hemorrhages Microaneurysms Cotton wool spots Hard exudates.

Extraedge:

Pathophysiology DR is a microangiopathy primarily affecting the precapillary arterioles capillaries, venules and post capillary venules. The basic components of the damaging process are microvascula occlusion & microvascular leakage. Capillary changes: Degeneration & loss of pericytes Thickening of Basement membrane Damage & proliferation of endothelial cells Hematological changes: Deformation of RBC & rouleaux formation Increased plasma viscosity Increased platelet stickiness & aggregation

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A patient came history of penetrating trauma and diagnosis of sympathetic ophthalmitis was made. Which of the following will be seen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pan Uveitis This case is a classic scenario of sympathetic ophthalmitis ; which is an example of panuveitis. It refers to B/L granulomatous panuveitis caused by trauma to one eye. The injured eye acts as an exciting eye while the other eye acts as the sympathizing eye. Causes : Penetrating/perforating injury Metallic foreign body Injury to ciliary body Pathology : Injury to ciliary body → Uveal pigments released → Act as antigens/foreign bodies →Ag-Ab reaction → Uveitis due to inflammation → Abs attack ciliary body of healthy eye → Uveitis of both eyes Patients typically present with non-specific symptoms of ocular inflammation, including blurred or decreased vision, pain, photophobia and conjunctival injection. Typically, reduction of near vision is an early symptom. The onset can be insidious or acute. Sympathetic ophthalmia is characterized by inflammation involving any part and most of the uveal tract.

Highyeild:

Effects Of Penetrating Injury Mechanical effects of the trauma Introduction of infection Post-traumatic iridocyclitis Sympathetic ophthalmitis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A - Anterior segment findings include keratic precipitates, anterior chamber reaction, posterior synechiae and the development of a cataract. Option B - In eyes with chronic inflammation, either elevated pressures from inflammatory glaucoma or hypotony from ciliary body shutdown can develop. Option C - Pars planitis is a disease of the eye that is characterized by inflammation of the narrowed area (pars plana) between the colored part of the eye (iris) and the choroid . This may lead to blurred vision; dark, floating spots in the vision; and progressive vision loss. Right eye showing mutton fat keratitic precipitates more inferiorly Left eye shows a physical eye with a corneoscleral tear repair

Extraedge:

Slit Lamp Examination Conjunctiva:- Foreign Bodies Hemorrhagic Chemosis Conjunctival laceration Cornea Epithelial Defect Corneal Laceration (length, depth, width Sclera Scleral laceration/ Rupture Anterior Chamber Cells, fibrin, FB in AC Depth of AC Iris and Angle Iris prolapse/plugging the wound Sphincter tear Iridodialysis Iridodonesis Cyclodialysis Crystalline Lens Phacodonesis Subluxation Dislocation Rupture of Anterior / Posterior Capsule Intralenticular FB Posterior Segment examination Vitreous haemorrhage Retinal detachment Retinal dialysis Retinal tear Posterior vitreous detachment Choroidal rupture Optic nerve trauma. IOFB

questions.text: Spot the following image and find the correct diagnosis ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pseudoexfoliation Syndrome Given is a classic image of Pseudoexfoliation syndrome. Pseudoexfoliation syndrome is a chronic, age-related disorder of the extracellular matrix that results in the deposition of abnormal fibrillary (pseudoexfoliative) material within various body tissues. However, this condition manifests primarily in the anterior segment of the eye.

Highyeild:

Clinical and Pathological changes:- Corneal changes (pseudoexfoliation endotheliopathy) Flakes of pseudoexfoliation material and pigment accumulation on the corneal endothelium (diffuse or as a vertical spindle similar to the Krukenberg spindle) Specular microscopy of the corneal endothelium Significantly lower than normal cell density and changes in cell size and shape. Iris changes :- Pseudoexfoliation material seen as white flecks on the pupillary margin of the iris , with loss of pigment at the pupillary ruff Lens, zonule and ciliary body changes:- The characteristic appearance of PEX material on the anterior lens capsule has three distinct zones: a translucent , central disc with occasional curled edges a clear zone ; a peripheral granular zone , which may have radial striations

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B: Trauma to the eye may manifest as rosette-like cataracts or trauma pattern that is typical to the mechanism and cause of injury. Option C: Option D:

Extraedge:

Etiology and Pathogenesis:- Grey-white fibrillary extracellular material composed of a protein core surrounded by GAG's is produced by abnormal BM of ageing epithelial cells in the trabeculae , equatorial lens capsule, iris and ciliary body Deposited on the anterior lens capsule, zonules , ciliary body, iris, trabeculae, anterior vitreous face and conjunctiva Inherited microfibrillopathy ➡️ ultrastructural appearance of random 10 to 12 m fibrils , arranged in a fibrillar granular matrix or coiled as spirals The material behaves like a sticky " Christmas tree " type of protein , aggregating a large number of elastic tissue and basement membrane proteins Polymorphisms in the coding of LOXL1 gene. LOXL1 enzyme- essential for formation of elastin fibres

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Patient of Rheumatoid arthritis presents with this ocular finding. Diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Scleromalacia Perforans Anterior necrotizing scleritis without inflammation, so called scleromalacia perforans, is a rare, severe eye disorder developing an autoimmune damage of episcleral and scleral performing vessels (hypersensitivity type III). Scleromalacia perforans consist of scleral melting in a white, quiet eye.

Highyeild:

Differential diagnosis:- Scleral Hyaline Plaque: age-related hyaline degeneration of the sclera. Plaque lies in the palpebral fissure immediately anterior to the medial rectus muscle insertion. Senile Scleromalacia: is a scleral disease which occurs by expulsion of a calcified plaque in advanced cases of senile scleral plaques.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A: Option C: Option D: Total if they involve a whole sector of the iris up to the ciliary body keyhole" defect Partial if they do not involve a whole sector of the iris may appear as a notch at the pupillary margin

Extraedge:

Risk Factors:- Scleromalacia perforans typically occurs in elderly women with long-standing rheumatoid arthritis. Other associated conditions are:- systemic lupus erythematosus, periarteritis nodosa, granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener granulomatosis), Behçet disease, limited scleroderma, Crohn’s disease, graft-versus-host disease.

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: This surgery is done for which of the following ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Keratoconus Image given shows the INTAC Intrastromal corneal ring segments (2 PMMA ring segments) are seen here. They flatten the cornea by shortening the arc length due to which visual acuity increases in cases of existing keratoconus. Indications: Progressive loss of vision Clear central stroma Corneal thickness> 450 microns at site o entry Delay/to eliminate keratoplasty as main management

Highyeild:

Classical signs of keratoconus:- Fleischer's ring:- an iron colored ring surrounding the cone Vogt's striae:- stress lines caused by corneal thinning Apical scarring:- scarring at the apex of the cone Corneal thinning:- In advanced cases, the thinning of the central cornea can be seen on examination. Visual Acuity:- Reduced visual acuity due to oblique astigmatism Retinoscopy:- scissor reflex Ophthalmoscopy:- Oil droplet

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Keratoglobus - Keratoglobus is a rare, noninflammatory corneal ectasia characterized by diffuse protrusion and thinning of the cornea. Option C - Vogt Limbal Girdle - Vogt's limbal girdle is a corneal degeneration usually seen in elderly individuals. This is the first time it is seen in association with retinitis pigmentosa . Option D - Keratectomy - Photorefractive keratectomy and laser-assisted subepithelial keratectomy are laser eye surgery procedures intended to correct a person's vision, reducing dependency on glasses or contact lenses. Keratoconus is a condition where the cornea, typically a dome like round structure that helps focus light as it enters the eye,becomes bulged and deformed into a more conical shape.

Extraedge:

Risk Factors Cause Unknown Family History Down Syndrome. Marfan Syndrome. & Ehlers Danlos History Of Other Eye Conditions (Ex. Aniridia) Chronic Eye Rubbing Signs & Symptoms Visual Impairment Refractive Errors Irregular Astigmatism Abnormal Cornea Curvature Cornea May Bulge In Cone Shape During Exam Acute Hydrops Reduced Vision

Table:
